Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The alarm blared just as I was scrubbing the lobby floor, gloves on my hands, the scent of disinfectant sharp in the air. As a housekeeping cleaner, I’m drilled to follow every safety and hygiene protocol—gloves on, hands washed, never touch my face. But as the water started seeping under the front doors, panic rose with it. I could see people outside, neighbors and strangers, some struggling to move their cars, others shouting for help. As a citizen, I know I’m supposed to help in emergencies, to look out for others, to be part of the community that stands together in crisis. But my hands were covered in chemicals, and I wasn’t supposed to remove my gloves until I’d finished and washed up. If I rushed out to help, I’d risk spreading germs or exposing myself to something worse. If I stayed, I’d be ignoring people who might need me. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between the rules of my job and the call of my conscience, the floodwater inching closer.
